column2: And then her own work in the matter, which should have culminated at one o'clock in Lord Grenville's dining-room, when the relentless agent of the French Government would finally learn who was this mysterious Scarlet Pimpernel, who so openly defied an army of spies and placed himself so boldly, and for mere sport, on the side of the enemies of France.

column2: But now, suddenly, as Suzanne prattled merrily along, an awful horror came upon her for what she had done.

column2: My Lord Hastings came to see maman early this morning.

column2: He said that all is now well with dear papa, and we may safely expect him here in England in less than four days."
column3: He said that all is now well with dear papa, and we may safely expect him here in England in less than four days."

column2: Oh! how could she have been so blind?

column2: And all for the sheer sport and devilry of course!--saving men, women and children from death, as other men destroy and kill animals for the excitement, the love of the thing.

column2: No wonder that Chauvelin's spies had failed to detect, in the apparently brainless nincompoop, the man whose reckless daring and resourceful ingenuity had baffled the keenest French spies, both in France and in England.

column2: Here lay the whole awful, horrible, amazing puzzle.

column2: In betraying a nameless stranger to his fate in order to save her brother, had Marguerite Blakeney sent her husband to his death?

column2: Child as she was, she felt the poignancy of her friend's grief, and with the infinite tact of her girlish tenderness, she did not try to pry into it, but was ready to efface herself.
column3: Child as she was, she felt the poignancy of her friend's grief, and with the infinite tact of her girlish tenderness, she did not try to pry into it, but was ready to efface herself.

column2: Just as little Suzanne was about to mount the terrace steps, a groom came running round the house towards his mistress.
column3: Just as little Suzanne was about to mount the terrace steps, a groom came running round the house towards his mistress.

column2: He carried a sealed letter in his hand.

column2: Suzanne instinctively turned back; her heart told her that here perhaps was further ill news for her friend, and she felt that poor Margot was not in a fit state to bear any more.
column3: Suzanne instinctively turned back; her heart told her that here perhaps was further ill news for her friend, and she felt that poor Margot was not in a fit state to bear any more.

column2: The groom stood respectfully beside his mistress, then he handed her the sealed letter.
column3: The groom stood respectfully beside his mistress, then he handed her the sealed letter.

column3: What is that? asked Marguerite.

column2: Just come by runner, my lady.

column3: Marguerite took the letter mechanically, and turned it over in her trembling fingers.

column2: Who sent it? she said.

column3: The runner said, my lady, replied the groom, "that his orders were to deliver this, and that your ladyship would understand from whom it came."

column2: Already her instinct told her what it contained, and her eyes only glanced at it mechanically.
column3: Already her instinct told her what it contained, and her eyes only glanced at it mechanically.

column3: Marguerite's senses reeled, her very soul seemed to be leaving her body; she tottered, and would have fallen but for Suzanne's arm round her waist.

column2: With superhuman effort she regained control over herself--there was yet much to be done.

column2: Bring that runner here to me, she said to the servant, with much calm. "He has not gone?"
column3: Bring that runner here to me, she said to the servant, with much calm. "He has not gone?"

column2: No, my lady.

column2: She kissed Marguerite tenderly and obeyed without a word; the child was overawed by the terrible, nameless misery in her friend's face.

You may go." Then she turned to the groom: "My coach and the four swiftest horses in the stables, to be ready at once."

column2: Marguerite remained standing for a moment on the lawn quite alone.
column3: Marguerite remained standing for a moment on the lawn quite alone.

column2: Her graceful figure was as rigid as a statue, her eyes were fixed, her hands were tightly clasped across her breast; her lips moved as they murmured with pathetic heart-breaking persistence,--
column3: Her graceful figure was as rigid as a statue, her eyes were fixed, her hands were tightly clasped across her breast; her lips moved as they murmured with pathetic heart breaking persistence,--

column2: What's to be done?	What's to be done?
What's to be done?

column2: Where to find him?--Oh, God! grant me light."

column2: But this was not the moment for remorse and despair.
column3: But this was not the moment for remorse and despair.

column2: She had done--unwittingly--an awful and terrible thing--the very worst crime, in her eyes, that woman ever committed--she saw it in all its horror.
column3: She had done-unwittingly-an awful and terrible thing-the very worst crime, in her eyes, that woman ever committed-she saw it in all its horror.

column2: She ought to have known! she ought to have known!
column3: She ought to have known! she ought to have known!

column2: How could she imagine that a man who could love with so much intensity as Percy Blakeney had loved her from the first--how could such a man be the brainless idiot he chose to appear?
column3: How could she imagine that a man who could love with so much intensity as Percy Blakeney had loved her from the first-how could such a man be the brainless idiot he chose to appear?

column2: She, at least, ought to have known that he was wearing a mask, and having found that out, she should have torn it from his face, whenever they were alone together.
column3: She, at least, ought to have known that he was wearing a mask, and having found that out, she should have torn it from his face, whenever they were alone together.

column2: But there was no time now to go over the past.
column3: But there was no time now to go over the past.

column2: By her own blindness she had sinned; now she must repay, not by empty remorse, but by prompt and useful action.
column3: By her own blindness she had sinned; now she must repay, not by empty remorse, but by prompt and useful action.

column2: Percy had started for Calais, utterly unconscious of the fact that his most relentless enemy was on his heels.
column3: Percy had started for Calais, utterly unconscious of the fact that his most relentless enemy was on his heels.

column2: He had set sail early that morning from London Bridge.
column3: He had set sail early that morning from London Bridge.

column2: Provided he had a favourable wind, he would no doubt be in France within twenty-four hours; no doubt he had reckoned on the wind and chosen this route.
column3: Provided he had a favourable wind, he would no doubt be in France within twenty four hours; no doubt he had reckoned on the wind and chosen this route.

column2: Chauvelin, on the other hand, would post to Dover, charter a vessel there, and undoubtedly reach Calais much about the same time.
column3: Chauvelin, on the other hand, would post to Dover, charter a vessel there, and undoubtedly reach Calais much about the same time.

column2: Once in Calais, Percy would meet all those who were eagerly waiting for the noble and brave Scarlet Pimpernel, who had come to rescue them from horrible and unmerited death.
column3: Once in Calais, Percy would meet all those who were eagerly waiting for the noble and brave Scarlet Pimpernel, who had come to rescue them from horrible and unmerited death.

column2: With Chauvelin's eyes now fixed upon his every movement, Percy would thus not only be endangering his own life, but that of Suzanne's father, the old Comte de Tournay, and of those other fugitives who were waiting for him and trusting in him.
column3: With Chauvelin's eyes now fixed upon his every movement, Percy would thus not only be endangering his own life, but that of Suzanne's father, the old Comte de Tournay, and of those other fugitives who were waiting for him and trusting in him.

column2: Unfortunately, she could not do all this quite alone.
column3: Unfortunately, she could not do all this quite alone.

column2: Once in Calais she would not know where to find her husband, whilst Chauvelin, in stealing the papers at Dover, had obtained the whole itinerary.
column3: Once in Calais she would not know where to find her husband, whilst Chauvelin, in stealing the papers at Dover, had obtained the whole itinerary.

column2: Above every thing, she wished to warn Percy.
column3: Above every thing, she wished to warn Percy.

column2: She knew enough about him by now to understand that he would never abandon those who trusted in him, that he would not turn his back from danger, and leave the Comte de Tournay to fall into the bloodthirsty hands that knew of no mercy.
column3: She knew enough about him by now to understand that he would never abandon those who trusted in him, that he would not turn his back from danger, and leave the Comte de Tournay to fall into the bloodthirsty hands that knew of no mercy.

column2: But if he were warned, he might form new plans, be more wary, more prudent.
column3: But if he were warned, he might form new plans, be more wary, more prudent.

column2: Unconsciously, he might fall into a cunning trap, but--once warned--he might yet succeed.
column3: Unconsciously, he might fall into a cunning trap, but-once warned-he might yet succeed.

column2: Her whole body stiffened as with a great and firm resolution.
column3: Her whole body stiffened as with a great and firm resolution.

column2: This she meant to do, if God gave her wits and strength.
column3: This she meant to do, if God gave her wits and strength.

column2: Her eyes lost their fixed look; they glowed with inward fire at the thought of meeting him again so soon, in the very midst of most deadly perils; they sparkled with the joy of sharing these dangers with him--of helping him perhaps--of being with him at the last--if she failed.
column3: Her eyes lost their fixed look; they glowed with inward fire at the thought of meeting him again so soon, in the very midst of most deadly perils; they sparkled with the joy of sharing these dangers with him-of helping him perhaps-of being with him at the last-if she failed.

column2: The childlike sweet face had become hard and set, the curved mouth was closed tightly over her clenched teeth.
column3: The childlike sweet face had become hard and set, the curved mouth was closed tightly over her clenched teeth.

column2: She meant to do or die, with him and for his sake.
column3: She meant to do or die, with him and for his sake.

column2: A frown, which spoke of an iron will and unbending resolution, appeared between the two straight brows; already her plans were formed.
column3: A frown, which spoke of an iron will and unbending resolution, appeared between the two straight brows; already her plans were formed.

column2: She would go and find Sir Andrew Ffoulkes first; he was Percy's best friend, and Marguerite remembered, with a thrill, with what blind enthusiasm the young man always spoke of his mysterious leader.
column3: She would go and find Sir Andrew Ffoulkes first; he was Percy's best friend, and Marguerite remembered, with a thrill, with what blind enthusiasm the young man always spoke of his mysterious leader.

column2: He would help her where she needed help; her coach was ready.
column3: He would help her where she needed help; her coach was ready.

column2: A change of raiment, and a farewell to little Suzanne, and she could be on her way.
